title: Photographer Jan Stel Europe travels Europe collecting pictures of abandoned buildings
text:
1

An explorer has spent more than a decade travelling across Europe, photographing its abandoned ruins.
Jan Stel's 'Abandoned and Forgotten' series has seen him visit the likes of old animal testing labs, steel works, subway tunnels and textile factories.
The photographer, from Purmerend, Netherlands, came up with the idea for his series in 1998, when his interests in past glories was initially piqued by the remains of industrial structures.
Dutch photographer Jan Stel has spent 15 years travelling Europe to capture images of abandoned buildings, including this subway in Premetro, Belgium
Over 15 years, Jan has travelled to Belgium, France, Germany, Spain, and many other countries across the continent in pursuit of the pictures.
He said: 'Abandoned locations have something magical: a hidden world left by men, but still full of life and history.
 Next Disappearing world: Pictured the crumbling village of... Dancing bears, daredevil motorbike stunts and shooting... I'm a big boy now! Heart-warming moment baby elephant thinks... 'I have been fascinated by nature and the absence of human kind.
'It is also about Mother Earth taking back what once belonged to her and over the years transforming a location more and more.'
The morning sun casts a warming light on these stone arches in Cathedral de Vino, Spain, which Jan visited in 2013
Jan used only natural light to illuminate his shots at this abandoned bus station in France, creating an eerie effect
Once he has arrived at a suitable abandoned building, Jan looks for interesting light sources, playing around with the likes of shadows in his imagery.
When shooting, Jan only uses natural light to illuminate his shots, resisting the urge to use a lighting rig or even a torch.
He also looks for interesting details within buildings, shooting a range of wide angle images, to show decay and scale, as well as close-ups of important items left behind.
These items can range from a rusting tool to segments of machinery - all of which help tell the story of the location's past glories.
The remains of work at a chemical lab in Belgium are pictured here, with liquids and animal remains still presents in jars
Old files at a crumbling textiles factory in Spain show much was left behind after the decisions was made too shut down the plant
Through the series, the photographer hopes to display an abandoned world that is different from the vandalised buildings that many people associate with decay.
He added: 'It's all about feel - being one with the location and waiting for the right moment.
'I mostly prefer to explore on my own, then all senses are sharp and focused and I can enjoy the full potential of a location that has so much to show.
'These fascinating places will cease to exist soon and their memories will fade away.
'I hope to sensitively capture the characteristics of these places before they eventually become lost in time.'
